sem_template.sem_long_description: At-Bay recommends implementing MFA for all email users.

finding_templates.header: Implement Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for Email to prevent ransomware.
finding_templates.summary: This issue is important and may impact your premium or coverage.
finding_templates.description:
Multi-factor authentication (MFA) is a security setting that requires users to provide more than one method of verification to gain access to digital services such as email. Attackers often use stolen usernames and passwords to access email accounts and use that to gain additional access to systems in the IT environment and expand the damage they create . Adding an additional verification method that cannot be stolen can help prevent an attack. 

_We determined your organization does not have MFA implemented for email._
finding_templates.how_to_fix: **At-Bay recommendation:** Implement MFA for all email users to prevent ransomware.
finding_templates.tech_content: We determined your organization does not have MFA implemented for email. At-Bay recommends implementing MFA for all email users. The most common and safest verification method is an authenticator application, such as Google Authenticator, which is recommended over text messages or phone calls. If you do not have the in-house technical resources to implement this fix, please contact your IT provider.
finding_templates.primary_resource_text: Learn how to Implement MFA for Email

sem_template.sem_header: Credential Dumping Risk via kcpassword on macOS
sem_template.sem_short_description: At-Bay detected a critical configuration vulnerability on your macOS devices: the kcpassword file is unprotected.
sem_template.sem_long_description: The kcpassword file is used to store login passwords on macOS when the automatic login feature is enabled, and if not properly secured, it poses a significant risk of credential dumping. This type of attack allows malicious actors to retrieve stored credentials, compromising user accounts and potentially granting unauthorized access to sensitive information. To mitigate this risk, we recommend disabling automatic login on all macOS devices, ensuring that the kcpassword file does not store passwords insecurely, and conducting regular audits of device security settings to prevent such vulnerabilities.

suggested_reading.title: How to protect Self-Managed Remote Access devices

sem_template.sem_short_description:
Recommended: Review and apply vendor security best practices for Remote access/VPN to help prevent ransomware attacks.
We identified that customers with a similar Remote Access/VPN are more likely to be attacked
sem_template.sem_long_description:
At-Bay recommendation:
1. Keep the device Up-to-Date: Ensure that your Remote Access/VPN device is running the latest software version and has all available patches applied. It is recommended to automatically install updates and if this is not possible to regularly check for updates and apply them promptly to enhance security.
2. Implement Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA): Make MFA mandatory for all users and administrators of the device.
3. Secure Administrative Web Interfaces: Close management login portals from being accessible via the public internet. If having internet facing login portal is necessary for business operations, access to it should be limited to specific IP addresses.
4. Enable Automatic Updates: Ensure that automatic software updates are turned on to keep your remote access/VPN systems up to date and secure.

discovered at least one exposed MS-SQL database port on your system. finding_templates.header: Close all exposed MS-SQL database ports to prevent data exfiltration.
finding_templates.summary: This issue is critical and must be resolved to bind your policy.

Microsoft SQL Server (MS-SQL) is a database management system that is used to store organizational data. Sensitive data is more likely to be exfiltrated when a port to a MS-SQL database is open. Attackers routinely scan the internet looking for exposed MS-SQL database ports, and an externally open port can expose your data to theft and threaten critical operations.

_We discovered at least one exposed MS-SQL database port on your system._
finding_templates.how_to_fix: **At-Bay requirement:** Close all exposed MS-SQL database ports to prevent attackers from gaining access to your system and exfiltrating your data. If an open MS-SQL database port is necessary for business operations, reinforce it with additional security measures so it is not exposed to the public internet.

suggested_reading.title: Encrypting Data Can Minimize the Impact of a Cyber Attack

finding_templates.header: Encrypt sensitive data to reduce the impact of a cyber attack.
finding_templates.summary: This issue is important and may impact your premium or coverage.
finding_templates.description:
Encrypted data can be read only by authorized users or software. In the event of a cyber attack, businesses with encrypted data often avoid the most significant costs because the data cannot be read by attackers, which makes it more difficult to exfiltrate.

_We determined the sensitive data stored on your servers and devices is not encrypted._
finding_templates.how_to_fix: **At-Bay recommendation:** Encrypt all sensitive data to reduce the potential impact of a cyber attack, including data stored on servers, laptops, mobile devices, and other portable media.
finding_templates.tech_content: We determined the sensitive data stored on your servers and devices is not encrypted. At-Bay recommends encrypting all sensitive data to reduce the potential impact of a cyber attack, including data stored on servers, laptops, mobile devices, and other portable media. We also recommend implementing strong passwords, enabling multi-factor authentication wherever possible, and reinforcing email and cloud encryption.
finding_templates.primary_resource_text: Learn how to encrypt sensitive data.

suggested_reading.title: Follow the 3-2-1 Rule When Creating Data Backups

sem_template.sem_short_description: Important: Backup sensitive data to avoid business interruption from ransomware.
sem_template.sem_long_description: At-Bay recommends creating backups to avoid business interruption in the event of a ransomware attack. To ensure your backups address all critical data, audit every data location to ensure nothing is excluded from the backups. When creating data backups, we recommend following the 3-2-1 Rule: Make 3 copies of the data, store the data across 2 different mediums, and keep 1 copy of the data off-site. To protect against ransomware, make sure the offsite backup is segregated from the business network. At-Bay also recommends performing frequent backups and practicing data restoration to ensure quick resolution in the event of an attack.

finding_templates.header: Back up sensitive data to avoid business interruption from ransomware.
finding_templates.summary: This issue is important and may impact your premium or coverage.
finding_templates.description:
Backups are copies of business data. Attackers often encrypt business data in a ransomware attack and demand payment for its release. Restoring data from backups is a reliable solution and helps avoid lost revenue due to business interruption. Without data backups, a business that experiences a ransomware attack can face the difficult decision of whether to pay the ransom or risk greater loss by refusing.

_We determined your sensitive data and critical systems are not backed up._
finding_templates.how_to_fix: **At-Bay recommendation:** Back up sensitive data and critical systems to prevent business interruption from ransomware. To ensure your backups address all critical data, audit all data locations to ensure nothing is excluded from the backups.
finding_templates.tech_content: We determined your sensitive data and critical systems are not backed up. To ensure your backups address all critical data, audit every data location to ensure nothing is excluded from the backups. When creating data backups, we recommend following the 3-2-1 Rule: Make 3 copies of the data, store the data across 2 different mediums, and keep 1 copy of the data off-site. To protect against ransomware, make sure the offsite backup is segregated from the business network. At-Bay also recommends performing frequent backups and practicing data restoration to ensure quick resolution in the event of an attack.
finding_templates.primary_resource_text: Learn how to create data backups.

finding_templates.description: A password policy is an effective way to enforce email password guidelines and keep a business secure. Attackers often use lost or stolen credentials to gain unauthorized access to systems and launch cyber attacks, as more than 50% of all cyber attacks originate from an email-based compromise.
finding_templates.how_to_fix: **At-Bay recommendation:** Implement a strong password policy to prevent attackers from gaining unauthorized access to your employees email accounts.
finding_templates.tech_content: At-Bay recommends implementing a password policy that follows cyber security best practices, such as prompting employees to use special characters and prohibiting dictionary words. We also recommend forcing employees to change their passwords every 3-6 months to minimize the impact of a potential cyber attack, as well as blocking users after multiple failed password attempts to protect against brute force attacks.
finding_templates.primary_resource_text: Learn how to implement a strong password policy.

sem_template.sem_short_description: Recommended: Update unsecured TLS/SSL versions to prevent cyber attacks.

At-Bay recommends disabling the following TLS/SSL versions: TLS 1.0, TLS 1.1, SSL v2, and SSL v3. We also recommend disabling the following cipher suites: DES, 3DES, and RC4. To replace the outdated versions, enable TLS 1.2 and TLS 1.3 and use Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) ciphers.

Updating these certificates could prevent attackers from spoofing your website. If your certificate has expired, we recommend renewing it immediately. finding_templates.header: Update website security certificates to prevent spoofing.
finding_templates.summary: This issue is moderate and should be resolved to improve security.
finding_templates.description:
A website security certificate is a signed approval from a trusted third party known as a certificate authority (CA). Attackers often create fake websites that appear to be authentic, known as spoofing, and use them to gather your information for malicious purposes. However, a valid certificate lets visitors know a website is both authentic and trustworthy.

_We discovered at least one of your domains has an outdated certificate or is not signed by a CA._
finding_templates.how_to_fix: **At-Bay recommendation:** Update your security certificates on publicly available hosts to prevent attackers from spoofing your website. If your certificate has expired, renew it immediately. If your certificate is self-signed, get another one from a trusted CA.
finding_templates.tech_content: We discovered at least one of your domains has an outdated certificate or is not signed by a CA. At-Bay recommends immediately renewing any expired certificates one month prior to expiration. We also recommend using a certificate from a trusted CA, rather than a self-signed certificate. Self-signed certificates are not vetted in a trustworthy process and cannot be revoked by a CA, and they pose a serious risk when compromised.
finding_templates.primary_resource_text: Learn how to get a website security certificate.

case_studies.title: University of California
case_studies.long_text: The University of California had sensitive data compromised and exfiltrated in March 2021. Attackers exploited a vulnerability in its File Transfer Appliance. Sensitive information for hundreds of thousands of students, employees, and alumni was stolen, including Social Security numbers.
case_studies.short_text: The University of California had sensitive data compromised and exfiltrated in March 2021. Attackers exploited a vulnerability in its File Transfer Appliance. Sensitive information for hundreds of thousands of students, employees, and alumni was stolen, including Social Security numbers.

case_studies.title: Fortune 500 healthcare company has 365,000 patient and employee data exfiltrated just before ransomware attack
case_studies.long_text: Magellan Health, April 2020. Magellan Health, a fortune 500 healthcare company based out of Phoenix, AZ fell victim to a cyber attack when a hacker deployed a successful phishing scheme and used social engineering to access the healthcare companys systems. Over the course of a few days, the attacker exfiltrated sensitive employee and patient records, and then demanded a ransom from Magellan. An investigation of the situation determined that the hacker installed malware that enabled them to access credentials to log into the system. The compromised data in this attack included information such as social security numbers, taxpayer identification, W-2s, patient treatment and insurance information, affecting nearly 365,000 patients and employees.
case_studies.short_text: Magellan Health, a Fortune 500 healthcare company, learned an attacker used phishing techniques to disseminate malware in April 2020. The attacker accessed login credentials and exfiltrated 365,000 employee and patient records, including Social Security numbers, before launching a ransomware attack.

case_studies.title: Small doctor's office ignores ransom and loses all patient information
case_studies.long_text: Brookside ENT and Hearing Center, March 2019. A small doctors office in Michigan, closed its practice after the two-doctor office was hit with a ransomware attack. The doctors lost access to important and sensitive information that affected their ability to perform their jobs when the hacker encrypted the data and demanded a $6,500 ransom. Out of fear that there was no guarantee that they would receive their files back, the doctors chose not to pay the ransom, and the attack deleted all of their information and it could not be recovered. Investigators determined that the hacker did not access patients were at minimal risk of fraud because the hackers didnt access the patient data before locking and deleting the files, but the situation caused issues for their patients whose medical records were deleted during the attack.
case_studies.short_text: Brookside ENT, a small doctor's office in Michigan, shuttered its practice after a ransomware attack in March 2019. The attacker demanded a $6,500 ransom to return their data, and the two doctors chose not to pay. As a result, all patients medical data was deleted and could not be recovered.

case_studies.header: Cyber Incidents in Transportation and Logistics
case_studies.title: A leading US transportation business loses millions after a ransomware attack, according to a regulatory filing.
case_studies.long_text: Forward Air had to temporarily suspend its electronic data interfaces with its customers leading to an estimated $7.5M in lost revenue in the fourth quarter of 2020. These costs were in addition to the incremental costs of the damage and recovery.
case_studies.short_text: Forward Air, a leading transportation company, suffered a ransomware attack that led to the suspension of electronic data interfaces with its customers. The attack resulted in an estimated $7.5 million in lost revenue in Q4 of 2020, as well as incremental damage and recovery costs.

case_studies.header: Cyber Incidents in Transportation and Logistics
case_studies.title: Transportation and trucking company suffers ransomware attack followed by data exfiltration.
case_studies.long_text: Manitoulin 2020: Ransomware attack followed by data exfiltration. Attack was in July but data leak happened in September. They did not pay the hackers, so this is a common tactic to maintain your reputation as a ransomware criminal and encourage future victims to pay - or else. We didnt believe they had enough information that was concerning to us, said Manitoulin Transport President Jeff King.
case_studies.short_text: Manitoulin, a small Canadian transportation company, suffered a ransomware attack followed by data exfiltration in 2020. The company claimed it did not believe the hacker had enough information concerning them and decided not to pay the ransom, which resulted in the data leak.

case_studies.title: Event Equipment Manufacturer Data Breach
case_studies.long_text: Tait Towers, June 2020.  Tait Towers Manufacturing, a producer of rigging, lighting and other equipment for concerts and festivals, experienced unauthorized access to their server in February. They didnt detect it until April and did not disclose the incident for another 2 months.
case_studies.short_text: Tait Towers, a small event equipment manufacturer, experienced a server breach by an unauthorized third party in February 2020. The breach was detected two months later and disclosed to partners and clients four months later, a timeline that expanded the scope of the damage.

case_studies.title: Large Aerospace Manufacturer Data Exfiltration and Ransomware Attack
case_studies.long_text: Visser Precision. March 2020. Visser Precision, a large manufacturer of aerospace parts, confirmed a data breach caused by a ransomware attack called DoppelPaymer. A website published their stolen files including those carrying information for Tesla, Boeing, SpaceX and Lockheed Martin. Certain files were even downloadable. This was the result of an unpaid extortion demand. The hacking group has set up a site to leak all unpaid extortion files
case_studies.short_text: Visser Precision, a large automotive and aeronautical manufacturer, experienced a DoppelPaymer ransomware attack in 2020. As a result of an unpaid ransom, the attacker leaked stolen files, including those with client information for Tesla, Boeing, SpaceX, and Lockheed Martin.

case_studies.title: Fintech Servers Hit with Ransomware Causes Major Business Interruption
case_studies.long_text: Finastra, March 2020. Finastra, a fintech company worth $2B and with more than 8,500 customers, faced a ransomware attack that forced them to shut down a number of servers and send home thousands of employees. Over the three days before being discovered, the attacker installed Ryuk ransomware on a number of Finastras cloud servers and encrypted data, causing major business interruption to their company and their partnering banks and service providers.
case_studies.short_text: Finastra, a large fintech company, experienced a ransomware attack in 2020. The software attack caused major business interruptions to the company and its partnering banks and service providers. Finastra was forced to shut down multiple servers and send home thousands of employees.

case_studies.title: National wholesale insurance broker suffers leaked data due to unpaid ransomware extortion
case_studies.long_text: USG Insurance services, a national wholesale insurance broker, suffered a data breach that leaked 2 sets of data in 2 months time in 2020. The hacker asked for ransom to get the data back, and when the company didn't pay up, they leaked the rest of the data as well.
case_studies.short_text: USG Insurance Services, a national wholesale insurance broker, suffered a data breach in 2020 that leaked two sets of data within two months. The attacker demanded a ransom to return the data and, when the company didn't pay, leaked the rest of the data.

case_studies.title: Large internet technology company faces class action after discovering that hackers had full access to database
case_studies.long_text: In January 2021, a large internet technology company reported unauthorized access to their systems and are now facing a class action lawsuit. Customers were initially notified by the company that their credentials were compromised in January but did not mention that the hackers actually had access to their clients networks, routers and security products through administrative level permission on the database.
case_studies.short_text: Ubiquiti, a large internet technology company, reported unauthorized access to its systems in January 2021. Customers were notified their credentials were compromised, but attackers allegedly accessed client networks, routers, and security products. The company is now facing a class-action lawsuit.

case_studies.title: SME IT company managing hospital programs suffer large data breach
case_studies.long_text: In February of 2021, A San Antonio-based health IT company that helps hospitals manage their 340B drug programs, reported unusual activity in some of its files. Compromised files contained patient records with their names, birthdates and prescription details. There are at least 2,400,000 known victims affected, among at least 14 hospital systems. The company is now facing a class action lawsuit with plaintiffs seeking monetary damages and injunctive and declaratory relief.
case_studies.short_text: Capture Rx, a health IT company, reported unusual file activity in February 2021. Patient records with names, birthdates, and prescription details were allegedly compromised, affecting approximately 2.4 million people across 14 hospital systems. The company is now facing a class-action lawsuit.

case_studies.title: Malicious actor breached a large general contractors systems, accessing and transfering sensitive files
case_studies.long_text: At Hawaiian Dredging Construction Company (HDCC): "We have conducted an investigation into a security incident that resulted in unauthorized access to some of our systems. Our investigation determined that an unauthorized person accessed some of our systems at different periods between April 10, 2021 and April 17, 2021, and transferred some files out of our network. We reviewed the files that may have been involved. On July 7, 2021, we determined some of those files contained including one or more of the following elements: name, Social Security number, and/or financial account information."
case_studies.short_text: Hawaiian Dredging Construction Company, a large general contractor, discovered a breach in its systems in April 2021. An attacker compromised the information of more than 4,000 individuals, including Social Security numbers. The company has since provided identity theft monitoring to those affected.

case_studies.title: Regional millwright and rigging contractor's email accounts hacked and exploited
case_studies.long_text: July 16, 2021 - Cardinal Contracting is notifying 4,519 people nationwide who have been impacted by a recent data breach that exposed personal data, including medical information. The company stated it recently became aware of suspicious activity related to certain Cardinal Contracting email accounts and launched an investigation, with the assistance of third-party forensic specialists, to determine the nature and scope of the activity. Investigators determined there was unauthorized access to the email accounts between September 9 to December 8, 2020. The contracting company, a rigging and millwright contractor with branches in Michigan, Indiana, and Kentucky, said the information impacted by this event varied by individual but may include certain individuals' names, addresses, dates of birth, Social Security numbers, financial information, health insurance information, and medical information.
case_studies.short_text: Cardinal Contracting, a regional contractor based in Michigan, notified more than 4,500 individuals of exposed personal data in July 2021. A hacker gained access to company email accounts for three months and compromised medical information, financial data, and Social Security numbers.

case_studies.title: Barnes & Noble POS network down after hacking incident
case_studies.long_text: The company experienced systems failure, which affected NOOK content during the initial stages of the attack. Some users protested that they could not pay for their books or access their already purchased libraries. The disruption also affected brick and mortar stores where the point of sale systems across the United States suffered a major glitch. Restoration of its systems had taken longer than anticipated. The company stored customers details, such as billing and shipping addresses, email addresses, and phone numbers on the affected systems. Although the data breach did not compromise payment information, the exposed data could be combined with other details such as social security numbers to create personal profiles for identity theft purposes. Hackers could also use the customers purchase history to blackmail readers with embarrassing or sensitive reading preferences. Speculations suggest that Barnes & Nobles data breach involved a ransomware payload. The bookseller was alleged to have been running Pulse Secure VPN servers with an unpatched vulnerability CVE-2019-11510, which allows hackers to steal usernames and passwords to infiltrate corporate systems, install ransomware, and exfiltrate data.
case_studies.short_text: Barnes & Noble experienced a data breach to its corporate network in October 2020. The breach compromised email addresses, shipping information, phone numbers, and other data, though payment information was not exposed. There is speculation an unpatched vulnerability in its VPN server was exploited.

case_studies.title: Small, family owned bookstore falls victim to a breach exposing buyers to fraudulent charges on the payment cards
case_studies.long_text: "We recently discovered a data security incident involving our website. We immediately launched an investigation and engaged a digital forensics firm to assist. The recently completed investigation determined that payment card information may have been exposed for customers who made purchases through barristerbooks.com, lawbooks.com or lawbooksforless.com between July 7, 2020 and September 11, 2020. As a small, family-owned company serving law students since 1999, we have always taken the privacy and security of your information extremely seriously. We have never stored full card payment information in our customer accounts or servers and have always strived to maintain a high degree of security. Despite our protective measures, it appears that an unknown party was able to obtain payment card information at the time of order placement during the approximate eightweek period mentioned above. What Information Was Involved? The information involved in this incident may have included your name and the account number, expiration date, and card value verification number for your payment card ending in <>"
case_studies.short_text: BarristerBooks, a family-owned bookstore, experienced a data breach in November 2020. Over a three-month period, attackers accessed customers payment information, including names, account numbers, CVV codes, and expiration dates. As a result, customers received fraudulent charges on their cards.

case_studies.header: Cyber Incidents in Arts, Entertainment and Recretation
case_studies.title: Adventure-guide company hacked and sued for violating CCPA
case_studies.long_text: Backroads, an adventure-guide company, is facing a class-action lawsuit as of April 2021 due to a data breach it experienced in 2020. The company had worked with forensic specialists who found that a hacker had accessed and encrypted sensitive data, some of which included social security, health insurance and financial information.
case_studies.short_text: Backroads, an active travel company, experienced a data breach in 2020. Forensic specialists determined an attacker accessed and encrypted sensitive data, including Social Security numbers, health insurance data, and financial information. The company is facing a class-action lawsuit as of April 2021.

case_studies.header: Cyber Incidents in Arts, Entertainment and Recretation
case_studies.title: Atlanta Botanical Garden
case_studies.long_text: Atlanta Botanical Garden (ABG), an outdoor garden attraction, discovered in July 2020 that sensitive records were impacted by a third-party ransomware event in May 2020. A large computing company, which ABG uses for financial service tools, found that an attacker may have had access to ABG's unencrypted tax information on the third-party network, so ABG had to notify all those affected.
case_studies.short_text: Atlanta Botanical Garden, an outdoor garden attraction, discovered sensitive records were impacted by a third-party ransomware attack in May 2020. The computing company that was attacked initially reported certain records were inaccessible, but ABG learned attackers may have accessed unencrypted tax information.

case_studies.header: Cyber Incidents in Accomodation and Food Services
case_studies.title: 21c Museum Hotels Data Breach
case_studies.long_text: 21c Museum Hotels, a Louisville-based hotel chain, learned in March 2021 that a malicious actor hacked its employee email accounts through a phishing attack. Through forensic investigation, it found that over 2,300 individuals could have been affected by the data breach, which included Social Security information.
case_studies.short_text: 21c Museum Hotels, a Louisville-based hotel chain, learned in March 2021 an attacker accessed employee email accounts in a phishing attack. More than 2,300 individuals were potentially affected by the data breach, which included Social Security information.

case_studies.header: Cyber Incidents in Accomodation and Food Services
case_studies.title: Kings Seafood Company
case_studies.long_text: Kings Seafood Company, a restaurant group, experienced a cyber attack in June 2021. The attacker had access to payment card, medical, and drivers license information. A class-action lawsuit was filed against the company in October 2021.
case_studies.short_text: Kings Seafood Company, a restaurant group, experienced a cyber attack in June 2021. Attackers had access to payment card, medical, and drivers license information. A class-action lawsuit was filed against the company in October 2021.

case_studies.title: Leading supplier of seafoood in the Northeast experiences malware attack and data exfiltration.
case_studies.long_text: East Coast seafood group, a large supplier of seafoood in the Northeast, discovered that a previous malware attack had led to the malicious exfiltration of nearly 1,500 individual, sensitive records. In December 2020, a hacker encrypted their systems. Upon restoring the data and investigating the attack, it found that the hacker had also stolen data and posted it publicly.
case_studies.short_text: East Coast Seafood Group, a large seafood supplier, discovered nearly 1,500 sensitive records were accessed from November to December 2021 as a result of a past malware attack. Upon restoring the data and investigating the attack, the company learned the data was leaked.

case_studies.title: Small heating and plumbing supplier hit with malware attack
case_studies.long_text: Supply New England, a supplier of heating and plumbing products, experienced a malware attack that encrypted its files in November 2020. The company hired third-party resources to help investigate and restore systems. By February 2021, the company discovered sensitive data had been exfiltrated from its systems and posted publicly on two separate occasions. SNE notified the affected individuals.
case_studies.short_text: Supply New England, a supplier of heating and plumbing products, experienced a malware attack that encrypted its files in November 2020. After investigating and restoring systems, the company discovered an attacker exfiltrated sensitive data multiple times and notified the affected partners.

case_studies.title: Large law firm Cambell Conroy & O'neil falls victim to Ransomware attack
case_studies.long_text: Campbell Conroy & O'Neil, a law firm serving many Fortune 500 companies, experienced a ransomware attack in February 2021. The attackers had access to a wide array of sensitive data, including online account credentials, biometric data, Social Security numbers, and financial account information.
case_studies.short_text: Campbell Conroy & O'Neil, a law firm serving many Fortune 500 companies, experienced a ransomware attack in February 2021. The attackers had access to a wide array of sensitive data, including online account credentials, biometric data, Social Security numbers, and financial account information.
